We will need to form a basic understanding of basic scientific enterprise. Let us look at the slides. ## {{< fa chart-simple >}} Why Visualize? - We can digest information more easily when it is pictorial - Our [Working Memories](https://www.understood.org/en/articles/working-memory-what-it-is-and-how-it-works) are both *short-term* and *limited* in capacity. So a picture abstracts the details and presents us with an overall summary, an insight, or a story that is both easy to recall and easy on retention.\ - Data Viz includes *shapes* that carry strong cultural memories and impressions for us. These cultural memories help us to use data viz in a *universal way* to appeal to a wide variety of audiences. (Do humans have a gene for geometry?) - It helps sift facts and mere statements: for example: ![Rape Capital](/content/materials/images/rape-capital.png){fig-align="center"} ![What does Data Reveal?](/content/materials/images/data-reveals-crime.png){fig-align="center"} ## {{< iconify mdi category-plus >}} What are Data Types? {{< youtube dwFsRZv4oHA >}}

In the words of [S.S. Stevens](https://stats.idre.ucla.edu/other/mult-pkg/whatstat/what-is-the-difference-between-categorical-ordinal-and-interval-variables/) > the basic operations needed to create each type of scale is > cumulative: to an operation listed opposite a particular scale must be > added all those operations preceding it. ## What Are the Parts of a Data Viz? {#sec-data-viz} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## How to pick a Data Viz? Most Data Visualizations use one or more of the following geometric attributes or aesthetics. These geometric aesthetics are used to *represent* qualitative or quantitative variables from your data. ![Common Geometric Aesthetics in Charts](/content/materials/images/common-aesthetics-1.png){fig-align="center"} What does this mean? We can think of simple visualizations as **combinations** of these aesthetics.
